fields.value: Fiction and History: Polarity and Stylistic Gradience in Late Imperial Chinese Literature

dsDescriptionValue.value: This corpus consists of texts written in Chinese during the Ming and Qing dynasties, spanning roughly 1368 to the early 20th century (the newest text was written in 1916). The texts have been mostly pre-cleaned. The only English found in most of the files are indications of chapter or scroll breaks in the format ~~~START| Title of Chapter/Scroll |START~~~ This was done to ease breaking the texts into organic sections. Most of the corpus consists of texts found on wenxian.fanren8.com, a website that provides free access to Imperial Chinese literature. A number of texts were also found at projectgutenberg.org

fields.value: This repository includes code that can replicate the analysis within the article. To run the code, you will need to place the analysis.py and paulutility.py scripts in the same directory. "analysis.py" is the main program, and "paulutility.py" includes various helper functions.You can place the files to be analyzed in a "corpus" folder in the same directory. A "metadata.txt" file should be placed in the directory with the python files, and it should describe the files in the corpus folder. A "metadata.txt" file that can be used to analyze the documents with Chinese titles is included. "metadata.txt" should be a tsv file with the filename (minus extension), genre, title, era, and author (in that order). You will also need to include "ymetadata.txt" in the same directory. Metadata for the files with romanized titles is contained in the RomanNamedFiles.tsv file. Some of these works are duplicated in the files with Chinese character titles. Titles of texts treated as yeshi can be found in the YeshiFiles.tsv file. These are both tab separated files.

files.description: This zip contains approximately 900 late Imperial Chinese texts in .txt format.
files.label: ChineseCorpusFiles.zip
